1.text: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Thou art permitted to speak for thyself. Then Paul stretched forth the hand, and answered for himself:

2.text: I think myself happy, king Agrippa, because I shall answer for myself this day before thee touching all the things whereof I am accused of the Jews:

3.text: Especially [because I know] thee to be expert in all customs and questions which are among the Jews: wherefore I beseech thee to hear me patiently.

4.text: My manner of life from my youth, which was at the first among mine own nation at Jerusalem, know all the Jews;

5.text: Which knew me from the beginning, if they would testify, that after the most straitest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.

6.text: And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made of God unto our fathers:

7.text: Unto which [promise] our twelve tribes, instantly serving [God] day and night, hope to come. For which hopeâ€™s sake, king Agrippa, I am accused of the Jews.

8.text: Why should it be thought a thing incredible with you, that God should raise the dead?

9.text: I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.

10.text: Which thing I also did in Jerusalem: and many of the saints did I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I gave my voice against [them].

11.text: And I punished them oft in every synagogue, and compelled [them] to blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted [them] even unto strange cities.

12.text: Whereupon as I went to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,

13.text: At midday, O king, I saw in the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them which journeyed with me.

14.text: And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice speaking unto me, and saying in the Hebrew tongue, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? [it is] hard for thee to kick against the pricks.

15.text: And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And he said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.

16.text: But rise, and stand upon thy feet: for I have appeared unto thee for this purpose, to make thee a minister and a witness both of these things which thou hast seen, and of those things in the which I will appear unto thee;

17.text: Delivering thee from the people, and [from] the Gentiles, unto whom now I send thee,

18.text: To open their eyes, [and] to turn [them] from darkness to light, and [from] the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in me.

19.text: Whereupon, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision:

20.text: But shewed first unto them of Damascus, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the coasts of Judaea, and [then] to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, and do works meet for repentance.

21.text: For these causes the Jews caught me in the temple, and went about to kill [me].

22.text: Having therefore obtained help of God, I continue unto this day, witnessing both to small and great, saying none other things than those which the prophets and Moses did say should come:

23.text: That Christ should suffer, [and] that he should be the first that should rise from the dead, and should shew light unto the people, and to the Gentiles.

24.text: And as he thus spake for himself, Festus said with a loud voice, Paul, thou art beside thyself; much learning doth make thee mad.

25.text: But he said, I am not mad, most noble Festus; but speak forth the words of truth and soberness.

26.text: For the king knoweth of these things, before whom also I speak freely: for I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him; for this thing was not done in a corner.

27.text: King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest.

28.text: Then Agrippa said unto Paul, Almost thou persuadest me to be a Christian.

29.text: And Paul said, I would to God, that not only thou, but also all that hear me this day, were both almost, and altogether such as I am, except these bonds.

30.text: And when he had thus spoken, the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them:

31.text: And when they were gone aside, they talked between themselves, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds.

32.text: Then said Agrippa unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed unto Caesar.
